Acceptable Year of the Lord.note: The season of God’s favor proclaimed by Jesus, when captives are freed and broken hearts are healed.

Adar.note: Twelfth month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with the festival of Purim. Usually falls in February–March.

Age to Come.note: The promised future era under God’s reign, when righteousness dwells and tears are wiped away.

Appointed Time.note: A divinely chosen moment when God’s purpose unfolds—neither early nor late.

At Evening.note: The close of the day when lamps are lit and families gather, a common moment for offerings and reflection.

Av.note: Fifth month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with mourning for the destruction of the Temple. Usually falls in July–August.

beginning.note: The start of a period or event

Between the Evenings.note: An ancient expression for the time between afternoon and sunset, associated with Passover sacrifices.

Cockcrow.note: Pre-dawn hours marked by the rooster’s cry, remembered in Peter’s story of sorrow and grace.

Dawn.note: The first light that washes the night away—often a picture of hope after long waiting.

Day.note: Opposite of night; period of light between sunrise and sunset.

Day and Hour Unknown.note: Jesus’ teaching that the exact moment of His return is hidden, calling believers to watchfulness.

Day of Atonement.note: A solemn day of fasting and mercy when Israel sought cleansing and the slate was made clean.

Day of the Lord.note: Prophetic day of divine judgment and salvation—terror for the proud, shelter for the humble.

Days of Unleavened Bread.note: A week set apart to remember swift deliverance and to walk in sincerity and truth.

Due Season.note: God’s timing for harvest and reward, arriving right when weary hands are tempted to quit.

Dusk.note: The fading edge of daylight, when campfires glow and prayers rise like incense.

Early Rain.note: The first seasonal showers that soften the soil—symbol of fresh beginnings and God’s faithful provision.

eleventh hour.note: Also referred to as the fifth hour in biblical times. 11:00 a.m. – 12:00 p.m.

eleventh month.note: Shevat the eleventh month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in January–February.

Elul.note: Sixth month in the Hebrew calendar, a period of repentance and preparation for High Holy Days.

End of Days.note: A phrase for the culminating era of history when God brings all things to their appointed end.

evening.note: What comes after afternoon and before night; period of diminishing light from sunset to darkness.

Evening.note: The restful close of the day, often marked by sacrifice, song, and family remembrance.

Eventide.note: Another word for evening, the quiet hour when stories are told and hearts grow still.

Feast of Firstfruits.note: A joyful offering of the earliest sheaves—trusting God for the full harvest yet to come.

Feast of Tabernacles.note: A week of dwelling in booths, rejoicing in God’s sheltering presence through every wilderness.

Feast of Trumpets.note: A sacred day of shofar blasts, awakening hearts to repentance and readiness.

Feast of Weeks.note: Also called Pentecost—fifty days after Passover, celebrating harvest and the Giver of the Law.

fifth month.note: Av the fifth month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in July–August.

first day.note: Yom Rishon. The day after the Sabbath, marking the beginning of a new week.

first month.note: Nisan the first month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in March–April.

First Watch.note: The early night watch, when sentries take their posts and lamps begin to burn.

Firstfruits.note: The earliest portion offered to God—sign of the greater bounty on the way.

forty days.note: The period of time between the Exodus and the giving of the Law at Mount Sinai. Also the duration of Jesus' fast in the wilderness. A period symbolizing testing, trial, and preparation.

Forty Days.note: A sacred span of testing and renewal—from the flood to the wilderness fast.

Forty Nights.note: The long nights that accompany seasons of trial, watched over by a faithful God.

forty years.note: The period of time between the Exodus and the giving of the Law at Mount Sinai. Also the duration of Jesus' fast in the wilderness. A period symbolizing testing, trial, and preparation.

fourteenth day.note: The fourteenth day of the month, often associated with the Passover meal.

fourth day.note: The fourth day of the week, often associated with work and labor.

fourth month.note: Tammuz the fourth month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in June–July.

Fourth Watch.note: The deep night before dawn, when Jesus came walking on the sea to the fearful.

Fullness of Time.note: The moment when all threads meet—God sent His Son right on schedule.

Half Hour of Silence.note: A solemn hush in heaven before judgments unfold—weighty, reverent stillness.

Harvest Time.note: The season of gathering—sweat on the brow, joy in the barns, gratitude in the heart.

Heshvan.note: Eighth month in the Hebrew calendar, often associated with the rainy season in Israel.

High Sabbath.note: A festival Sabbath of special solemnity and joy, beyond the weekly rhythm of rest.

In the Beginning.note: The first word of Scripture’s story—God speaks, and light breaks the silence.

In Those Days.note: A narrative signpost that ushers in events of weight and wonder.

Jubilee Year.note: Every fiftieth year: debts released, land restored, slaves set free—good news embodied in time.

Kislev.note: Ninth month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with the festival of Hanukkah.

last day.note: The final day of a period or event

last days.note: The final days of a period or event

Latter Days.note: A prophetic horizon of fulfillment when God’s purposes ripen.

Latter Rain.note: The late-season showers that swell the grain—symbol of completion and refreshing grace.

Lyar.note: Second month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with springtime and renewal.

Mid-morning.note: The steady hours after sunrise, when work finds its stride and plans take form.

midday.note: 12:00 p.m. – noon. Also referred to as the sixth hour in biblical times.

Midday.note: The bright center of the day—heat at its height, shadows at their shortest.

midnight.note: 12:00 a.m. – midnight. Also referred to as the twelfth hour in biblical times. The beginning of the first watch.

Midnight.note: The turning point of dark to dawn—a time of sudden cries and opened prison doors.

Millennium.note: The thousand-year reign in Revelation—interpreted variously, but always under Christ’s lordship.

month.note: A period of time, typically 30 days, used in the Hebrew calendar.

morning.note: What comes after night and before noon; period of light from sunrise to midday.

Morning.note: The daily resurrection—mercies new, songs fresh, lamps unneeded.

Morning Watch.note: The last watch of the night when the sea parted and deliverance dawned.

Morrow.note: An older word for ‘tomorrow,’ the next day awaiting God’s mercies anew.

New Moon.note: The monthly renewal marked by offerings and joyful assembly.

Night.note: Opposite of day; period of darkness between sunset and sunrise.

ninth hour.note: Also referred to as the third hour in biblical times. 9:00 a.m. – 10:00 a.m.

ninth month.note: Tishri the ninth month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in September–October.

Nisan.note: First month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with the Exodus from Egypt.

Nissan.note: First month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with the Exodus from Egypt.

Noon.note: High sun and clear sight—a time of both fierce heat and frank dealings.

Passover.note: The night of deliverance remembered—lamb’s blood, hurried bread, and a swift exodus.

Preparation Day.note: The day before the Sabbath or a feast, when work is done early and hearts make ready.

Sabbath.note: God’s gift of holy rest—ceasing from toil to delight in the Creator.

Sabbath Year.note: Every seventh year the land rests, trust deepens, and God’s provision is remembered.

second month.note: Iyar the second month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in April–May.

second watch.note: 9 P.M. to midnight. The beginning of the second watch.

Second Watch.note: The later evening watch, when companions share stories to keep sleep at bay.

Seedtime.note: The season of putting promises into the ground, awaiting God’s increase.

seventh day.note: The seventh day of the week, often associated with rest and worship.

seventh hour.note: Also referred to as the seventh hour in biblical times. 7:00 p.m. – 8:00 p.m.

seventh month.note: Tishrei the seventh month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in September–October.

seventh year.note: The seventh year of the cycle, often associated with the sabbatical year.

Seventy Weeks.note: A prophetic period in Daniel’s vision mapping God’s redemptive timetable for Israel.

Seventy Years.note: The long exile foretold by Jeremiah—discipline with a promised return.

Shevat.note: Eleventh month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with winter and the renewal of trees.

Sivan.note: Third month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with the giving of the Law at Mount Sinai.

sixth day.note: Yom Shishi. Often associated with preparation for the Sabbath.

sixth hour.note: Also referred to as the sixth hour in biblical times. 6:00 p.m. – 7:00 p.m.

sixth month.note: Av the sixth month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in August–September.

Sundown.note: The moment the sun slips beneath the line and a new day begins in Hebrew reckoning.

sunrise.note: The time when the sun rises above the horizon. Marks the beginning of morning and day.

Sunrise.note: The golden edge of hope cresting the horizon—often the hour of answered prayer.

sunset.note: The time when the sun disappears below the horizon. Marks the beginning of evening and night.

Tammuz.note: Fourth month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with summer and the beginning of the harvest season.

tenth day.note: Often associated with the Day of Atonement. The tenth day of the seventh month, Tishrei.

tenth hour.note: Also referred to as the tenth hour in biblical times. 10:00 a.m. – 11:00 a.m.

tenth month.note: Teveth the tenth month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in December–January.

Teveth.note: Tenth month in the Hebrew calendar, often associated with winter and the festival of Hanukkah.

Third day.note: Jesus rose from the dead on the third day after His crucifixion. A day symbolizing victory over sin and death. The day after Shabbat.

Third Day.note: The day when the unexpected blooms—weddings are saved, and tombs are found empty.

third hour.note: Also referred to as the third hour in biblical times. 3:00 p.m. – 4:00 p.m.

third month.note: Hebrew month of Sivan, the third month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in May–June.

Third Watch.note: The deep quiet of night when faith keeps vigil and dreams are stirred.

Thousand Years.note: A millennium; Revelation’s long span under Christ’s authority.

Three Days and Three Nights.note: An idiom of completion recalled in Jonah and fulfilled in Christ’s burial and rising.

Time of Jacob’s Trouble.note: A prophesied season of distress for Israel, refining before deliverance.

Time, Times, and Half a Time.note: Apocalyptic shorthand for a limited period under God’s control—trial with an endpoint.

Times of Refreshing.note: Seasons of renewal from God’s presence after repentance and turning back.

Tishrei.note: Seventh month in the Hebrew calendar, associated with the High Holy Days and the Feast of Tabernacles.

twelfth month.note: Adar the twelfth month of the Hebrew calendar. It usually falls in February–March.

Twilight.note: The soft border between day and night, a threshold where prayers linger.

week.note: A period of seven days. Often associated with the creation week and the Sabbath.

Week.note: A seven-day rhythm anchored by rest and renewal.

year.note: A cycle around the sun. In the Hebrew calendar. This consists of 12 or 13 months.

Year and a Day.note: An old legal phrase echoing completeness beyond a single year.

year of jubilee.note: The fiftieth year in the cycle. Associated with the release of debts and the return of land.

Year of Jubilee.note: Trumpets sound liberty throughout the land—homecomings, fresh starts, and grace that resets the ledger.

Year’s End.note: The turning of the year—reckoning, remembrance, and resolve.

Yom Hamishi.note: Hebrew for fifth day of the week.

Yom Revi'i.note: Hebrew for fourth day of the week.

Yom Rishon.note: Hebrew for first day of the week, marking the beginning of a new week.

Yom Shabbat.note: Hebrew for seventh day of the week, the Sabbath.

Yom Sheni.note: Hebrew for second day of the week.

Yom Shishi.note: Hebrew for sixth day of the week.

Yom Shlishi.note: Hebrew for third day of the week.
